desc.size: Medium-sized shrub, to 3 m tall. Branches ascending and arching.

part.partText: reddish brownish to brown, egg-shaped, flattened, pointed, slightly hairy.

alternate, with yellowish to pinkish, 3 - 7 mm long, hairy leafstalks; dark green above, grayish green-waxy beneath, midrib yellowish to pinkish, 5 - 12 cm long, 1 - 3 cm wide, lanceolate to oblong-lanceolate, base rounded or heart-shaped, tip short-pointed, margins slightly wavy and irregularly toothed, margins slightly down-curved (revolute), smooth to minutely hairy above, hairy and wrinkled beneath, becoming hairless; young leaves brownish red, thin, translucent, minutely hairy.

either male or female, borne on separate trees (dioecious); in stalkless, cylindrical, hairy catkins; female catkins green to purplish, 1.5 - 4 cm long, scales blackish, stigmas red, ovary densely hairy; male catkins whitish, 1 - 2 cm long, scales blackish, stamens 2, anthers red turning yellow; insect- and wind-pollinated.
a capsule; in elongated clusters; short-stalked, brownish, 6 - 10 mm long, flask-shaped, hairy; seeds with long, white, silky hairs attached; dispersed by wind and water.

similarSpecies.comments: Salix humilis var. humilis is distinguished from most other willows in the Chicago Region by having hairless leaves and down-curved (revolute) leaf margins that are not distinctly toothed. Salix humilis var. tristis is similar to S. humilis var. humilis but on a smaller scale, with leaves that remain hairy, especially beneath. Salix pedicellaris, a small shrub that grows in bogs and fens, has leaves similar to both S. humilis varieties; however, the leaves of S. pedicellaris are finely net-veined on both sides and have parallel primary lateral veins.

speciesPage.flowering: Early April to early May, before the leaves.
speciesPage.habitatEcology: Frequent in moist to wet prairies. Also found in open woodlands and sandy areas, especially where there has been a history of fire.

etymology.comments: Salix is the Latin word for willow. Humilis means low-growing.
